text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Wednesday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- The statistics department issued more accurate data which shows a three percent rise in gross domestic product in 1995 at 23.829 billion litas.

- There are 44 people registered as infected with AIDS but the real figure could vary between 200 and 400 persons. The epidimeic is believed to be spreading from Belarus, Ukraine and Kaliningrad, the head of the AIDS center S. Caplinskas said during a conference on AIDS and sexually transmitted diseases.

- Another well-known criminal, Cheslavas Machnacius, was shot in Vilnius on Tuesday. Police officials believe a gang war has started and that the criminals are fighting over the redistribution of teritory in the capital.

- Parliament approved the formation of a new oil holding company Lietuvos Nafta by merging four oil companies, Mazheikiu Nafta, Butinges Nafta, Lietuvos Kuras and Naftotiekis. Right-wing opposition leader Gediminas Vagnorius warned that this law will be reconsidered after the October parliament elections.

- A wave of violence is rolling down from the nothern Lithuanian town of Panevezhys. Police officials believe that the attack against a chain of Vision Express shops on Sunday was connected to a protection racket run by Panevezhys criminals although the shop's management denies any threats.
- The free trade agreement on agricultural products between the three Baltic states will not come into force on October 1 as Latvian lawmakers have delayed the ratification of this law.
- Ukrainian President Leonid Kuchma finished a two-day official visit to Lithuania.

- Lithuanian, Latvian and Estonian defense ministers encouraged Western defence ministers to accept them into NATO during talks in Copenhagen since the U.S. Baltic Action Plan cannot be considered as an alternative to NATO membership.
- There have been 21 incidents at the Ignalina nuclear power plant this year. The newspaper investigates the problems with the safety and security systems of the plant.

- After the investigation of archive files on suspected war criminal Aleksandras Lileikis, the director of the special archives Arunas Bubnys says that to accuse Lileikis of the murder of 55,000 Jews during World War two, as stated by the U.S. Justice Department, is 'a total misunderstanding'. He says the only document which would indicate his personal involvement in the Jewish genocide is the copy of a letter that 55,000 Jews were passed by the Security Police to the Nazis and executed later although this copy has no signature.
- Lithuanian Finance Minister Algimantas Krizhinauskas signed a $75 million syndicated loan agreement with J.P. Morgan bank executive director Jean Facon in Vilnius.

- Vilnius council decided to take a short-term 35 million litas loan from the World Bank via the Lithuanian Savings Bank to pay debts to the energy system. 18 councils have already borrowed 77.3 million litas.
